comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wonderful panorama dated January 1871 (see note). I think the photo was originally made for an album sent to the Colonial Office in London, showing the achievements in NSW. That went into the National Archives UK who have also posted their version on Flickr, which happily includes all the ships' names! See - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nationalarchives/8188153610/] And the three individual photos which make up the panorama - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nationalarchives/8188123222/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nationalarchives/8188123150/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nationalarchives/8187042015/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It should be relatively simple to find out which day in January 1871 this was using Trove. About 10 or 11am by the warehouse shadows on the right!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Hmm - That's not going to work. All the named ships were at Circular Quay wharfs on the 20th and 27th January 1871, ie for at least a week. See these excellent SMH alphabetical lists of "Vessels in Harbour" - 20 Jan 1871 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13216860 27 Jan 1871 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13218966 And all the ships except 'Chance' were there the previous week - 13 Jan 1871 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13221911

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Well aren't I glad I posted this pic. Thanks for identifying the connection, its so great we can name all the vessels so accurately! The SLNSW has the same photograph, attributed to Charles Percy Pickering. It's not cropped & looks like it has the ships names pencilled beneath.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I had a feeling it was by Charles Pickering, or at least attributed to him.  He was probably under the direction of James Barnet, the NSW Colonial Architect.

The date "Jan 1871" on this version makes it extra special!  I wonder where the original glass plate negatives are?  Probably buried in State Records NSW Series 4481 with completely odd titles ...

comment.author: 26803874@N08
comment._content: This photo was taken by my ancestor, Charles Percy Pickering, one of Australia's first civic photographers.

comment.author: 26803874@N08
comment._content: Copies also held at State Library of NSW

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Here's a way-out-there suggestion. The fellow with the top hat talking with two friends (see note) might well be James Barnet. They are almost the only people standing still enough to show up, on a busy morning at Circular Quay. He seems to have had a habit of appearing as a loitering photographic assistant in some the 1872 album photos, when directing Charles Pickering - eg - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8123485772/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Fabulous! If its not Barnet then perhaps they went to the same milliner - that top hat looks familiar...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
